title: The true story that inspired 'Happy Face,' a drama about a serial killer and his daughter
summary: The true story that inspired “Happy Face,” a Paramount+ series about Keith Hunter Jesperson and his daughter Melissa Moore, plus what she said about him.
story: “Happy Face,” a Paramount+ series about a serial killer and his daughter, is based on a chilling true story.

Dennis Quaid plays Keith Hunter Jesperson, a convicted killer known as the Happy Face Killer. Jesperson’s nickname comes from the letters he sent to the media and authorities that contained a happy face, per the biography “I, the Creation of a Serial Killer” by Jack Olsen, which includes interviews with Jesperson and letters and writing by him.

Annaleigh Ashford is Melissa G. Moore, who, at 15, discovered her father was a serial killer, an experience she detailed in her 2009 memoir, “Shattered Silence: The Untold Story of a Serial Killer’s Daughter.” After publicly coming forward, Moore now works with families impacted by her father. She wrote in an essay for the BBC that she “received hundreds of emails from family members of other serial killers thanking me for telling my story, and asking for help and advice.”
Quaid, during a TODAY appearance, said he “wasn’t interested” in playing a serial killer, but was drawn to the part because of the father-daughter element.

“What made me do this — it’s about the relationship between and his daughter. It’s told from his daughter’s point of view. They had a loving relationship. Then he got caught and she discovered her dad was this monster serial killer,” Quaid said during an appearance on TODAY.
Here’s what to know.
Who is Keith Hunter Jesperson?
Jesperson, a long-haul trucker, is serving multiple life sentences in an Oregon prison for killing eight women in the 1990s.

In 2024, the Riverside County District Attorney’s Office in California asked for the public’s help identifying the last of Jesperson’s victims, whom Jesperson admitted to killing in 1992. As of now, the victim’s name has not been released.

Jesperson’s first victim was Taunja Bennett in 1990. He killed seven more women: Cynthia Lyn Rose, Patricia Skiple, Suzanne Kjellenberg, Laurie Ann Pentland, Angela May Subrize and a woman he called “Claudia.” The last of Jesperson’s known victims was his girlfriend Julie Winningham, whom he killed in 1995.

While awaiting trial in 1995, Jesperson confessed in a letter to his brother, Brad. “I am sorry that I turned out this way. I have been a killer for five years and have killed eight people. Assaulted more,” he said in the letter, The Associated Press reported.
Jesperson was born in British Columbia in April 1955, making him 69 years old.
Who is Melissa M. Moore?
Melissa M. Moore is one of Jesperson’s three children. Jesperson and his ex-wife, Rose Pernick, also had a daughter Carrie and a son Jason.
In her essay for the BBC, Moore detailed the last time seeing Jesperson before he went to prison.

At the time in 1994, Moore’s parents were divorced, and she said her father only dropped by occasionally. At breakfast at Denny’s Diner near her home in Spokane, Moore said Jesperson told her he had something “important” to tell her, but refused: “If I tell you, you will tell the police. I’m not what you think I am, Melissa.’”
In 1995, Moore said her mom told her Jesperson had been arrested for murder.
Moore said she would sneak out to the library to read reports of Jesperson’s trial. After reading her dad being called a “monster,” Moore said she stopped reading newspaper reports.
In “I, the Creation of a Serial Killer,” Jesperson recalls a visit from his children.

“Back in my cell I was pissed at myself for getting into this situation. My 15-year-old son Jason and 14-year-old daughter Melissa visited me through glass, and it only made things worse. The phone connection was bad and the guards rushed me away before we really started talking,” he wrote.
"I cried as they led me off. I felt sorry that my kids had to see me this way. I couldn’t even tell them I loved them. I had a feeling I wouldn’t see them again.”

Moore said she was able to “compartmentalize” what her father had done. But when she became a mother herself, she said she wanted to confront her past. “I realized that unless I addressed this issue properly, my father’s crimes would affect my daughter just as they had me,” she wrote.

Her first book, a memoir, came out in 2009; "WHOLE: How I Learned to Fill the Fragments of My Life with Forgiveness, Hope, Strength, and Creativity" was published in 2016. In addition to her book, Moore hosted the "Happy Face" podcast, about her story, and executive produced the Paramount+ series.

She also is an executive producer on other true crime works like Lifetime’s “The Life and Murder of Nicole Brown Simpson,” which spotlighted Nicole Brown Simpson’s life prior to her murder, and Lifetime’s series about Gypsy Rose Blanchard.
Moore and her father are not in touch, but she speaks to his victims

As of her 2014 essay, Moore had not spoken to her father in 10 years. She said her father sent a letter after her book came out that said, “I don’t want the world to judge me as a dad. I was a great dad. My only mistake was my eight errors in judgement.”
Moore shared her reaction to the letter in the the essay.

“He’s talking about murders! He’s calling them “errors in judgement”! That’s the way he sees things. How can anyone — even someone as close as a daughter — continue to have a relationship with a person who so completely lacks honesty and compassion?” she said.
Moore said she has been in touch with the family of Jesperson’s victims, including his first victim Taunja Bennett, and has spoken to Daun Slagle, the only woman who survived one of his attacks.
She believes her father should receive the death penalty. “I don’t say that for myself, but for his victims. Justice will never be served to them,” she said.

title: 'Opry 100' is streaming. How to watch the Grand Ole Opry's 100th anniversary event
summary: The Grand Ole Opry celebrated its 100th anniversary with a concert. Here's how to watch if you missed Opry 100 special and where it's streaming.
story: The Grand Ole Opry celebrated its 100th anniversary with an epic concert that aired on March 19 on NBC.
The special featured many moments that came as a delight for country fans — including a moving interaction between Randy Travis and Carrie Underwood and a Dolly Parton tribute from Reba McEntire.
Missed “Opry 100: A Live Celebration”? Here’s what to know about the special celebrating the Grand Ole Opry and how to watch.
What happened during the 'Opry 100: A Live Celebration'?
Blake Shelton hosted “Opry 100: A Live Celebration,” a three-hour TV special that blended musical performances with a bit of history about the Grand Ole Opry.
The performances took place from two venues in Nashville, Tennessee: the Grand Ole Opry House and Ryman Auditorium, which once housed the Opry.

“Becoming a member of the Opry is a highlight of my life and career, and 15 years later, I still get that same feeling of reverence and excitement every time I walk out on that stage. The Grand Ole Opry has been connecting the country music family for 100 years, and I’m so proud to be part of this historic celebration,” Shelton said in a statement, per NBC.
During a segment that aired on TODAY on March 19, Shelton said the concert would be like a "family reunion."
"This night is going to be like no other. This is one of those once in a lifetime things," he said.
When Shelton got his invitation to become a member of the Opry in 2010, it was "one of the biggest moments of my life, definitely the biggest moment of my musical career."
Where can I watch the 'Opry 100: A Live Celebration'?
Country fans could tune in to “Opry 100: A Live Celebration” live on Wednesday, March 19 from 8 to 11 p.m. ET on NBC.
Now, the special is available to stream on demand on Peacock.
Who performed at 'Opry 100'?
The all-star lineup featured country industry veterans and newbies alike, including several Opry members.
Shelton said on TODAY that having so many members of the Opry under one roof was going to be a “special” experience.
“Because to get all of us together in one place at one time is it’s almost impossible,” he said.

title: Carrie Underwood and Randy Travis move country fans to tears during 'Opry 100' special
summary: Carrie Underwood brought people to tears when she passed the microphone to Randy Travis while honoring him at the "Opry 100: A Live Celebration."
story: Carrie Underwood and Randy Travis shared a sweet moment at the "Opry 100: A Live Celebration."

At 100-year anniversary event, Underwood took the stage to honor Travis, who has won seven Grammys in his career. However, after suffering a stroke over a decade ago and developing aphasia, Travis has had limited ability to communicate.
To this day, he relies on his wife, Mary Davis, to help him speak during interviews.
Underwood led a tribute to Travis, performing two of his songs — "Three Wooden Crosses” and “Forever and Ever, Amen."
As she was nearing the end of the latter song, Underwood went into the audience and passed the microphone to Travis, who proudly sang the last "Amen" in the tune.
The audience was so taken by the moment that they gave the artists a standing ovation. Some were also seen wiping tears away. The internet's reaction was equally emotional.
"IM NOT CRYING YOU ARE 😭," one person said on X while sharing a video of Travis singing "Amen."
"🥺😭I was NOT ready," another added.
"😢That song gets me every time," a third said.
It was a full-circle moment for Underwood and Travis. In 2008, Travis surprised Underwood onstage with an invitation to join the Opry.
In her speech during the live celebration, the "American Idol" winner-turned-judge recalled the moment and also shared some kind words about Travis.

"When I was a kid, my sister had a cassette tape of Randy Travis' music. From the first time I heard him sing his traditional country voice and those songs, I was hooked, and I knew my sister was not getting that tape back," she said.

"The first time I met him, many years later, I cried — embarrassing, but it was so emotional for me to meet this man whose voice I've been singing to, and along with my whole life. I could never have imagined that I'd be recording songs with him, or that Randy would become my dear friend, or that he would surprise me on stage and invite me to join the Grand Ole Opry back in 2008," Underwood continued.
"It means so much to me to be here tonight to celebrate the Opry and the amazing Randy Travis by singing two of my favorite songs of his."

title: Reba McEntire leads Dolly Parton tribute at ‘Opry 100’ 2 weeks after her husband’s death
summary: Reba McEntire paid tribute to Dolly Parton at "Opry 100" after Parton's husband, Carl Dean, died earlier this month.
story: The country music community is rallying around Dolly Parton after her husband, Carl Dean, died earlier this month.
On March 19, Reba McEntire shared words of support for the “Jolene” singer during NBC’s “Opry 100: A Live Celebration” in honor of the Grand Ole Opry’s 100th anniversary.
Parton wasn’t on hand for the event, but McEntire, who also paid tribute to other late country icons, let her know that she was missed and people were thinking about her.
“It’s been a great night of celebration, but of course, it’s just not the same without you,” McEntire said of Parton.
“Dolly, everybody here at the Opry and around the world wants to send you our thoughts and prayers. And you gotta know, we will always love you.”
The show then wound down with McEntire, Carrie Underwood and Lady A joining an all-star chorus singing Parton’s iconic track “I Will Always Love You.”
Before the performance, Parton had a video message for everyone at the “Opry 100: A Live Celebration."

“Well, hello, I am Dolly Parton and I am a proud member of the Grand Ole Opry, and I’m so sorry that I can’t be there with everybody in person. But, of course, you know my heart is with you and my spirit is with you,” she said.
On March 3, Parton announced her husband had died. She and Dean were married 59 years at the time of his death.
“Carl and I spent many wonderful years together,” the singer wrote on Instagram. “Words can’t do justice to the love we shared for over 60 years. Thank you for your prayers and sympathy.”
A few days later, Parton expressed her gratitude for the outpouring of support she had received.

“This is a love note to family, friends, and fans,” she wrote in a message shared on social media. “Thank you for all the messages, cards, and flowers that you’ve sent to pay your respects for the loss of my beloved husband Carl.
“I can’t reach out personally to each of you but just know it has meant the world to me,” she continued. “He is in God’s arms now and I am okay with that. I will always love you.”

In the wake of his death, Parton released a new song, “If You Hadn’t Been There" on March 6. The "9 to 5" singer also made her first public appearance since his passing at an opening day event for Dollywood season passholders on March 14, in honor of the theme park’s 40th season celebration in Tennessee.

“I just want all of you to know how much I appreciate you for everything that has happened to us in the last several years. But before I start all that, I just wanted to take a minute to thank all of you for all the flowers and the cards and the well wishes for the loss of Carl,” Parton told the crowd.

title: Who is Natalie Zettel? About Kris Jenner’s niece and the Kardashians‘ cousin
summary: The Kardashians’ cousin Natalie Zettel made a special appearance on Season 6 of the series. Learn all about the model and daughter of Kris Jenner's sister.
story: The Kardashians’ cousin Natalie Zettel made an appearance on Season 6, Episode 7, of “The Kardashians.”
Ahead of her March 2, 2025 wedding to boyfriend Noah Warren, Zettel stopped by her aunt Kris Jenner's house to try on wedding dresses in front of her family.
In a confessional, Jenner explained that she wanted to do something nice for Zettel, who is the daughter of her late sister, Karen Houghton, so she paid for her wedding gown.
“I really want to help her celebrate and make this a memory that she will keep in her heart forever,” Jenner said.
Jenner added, “I love a good wedding. But this is my treat for her. I told her that I really wanted to do her wedding dress so we’ll see if she likes them.”
Khloé Kardashian, who was also at the fitting, said she understood why Zettel might get emotional on her wedding day.

“When anyone is getting married, you have this vision of what you think that day is going to be like and I can only imagine Natalie always thought her mom would be here for such a beautiful day,” Kardashian said.
At the end of the fitting, Zettel decided to go with the first dress she tried on, a strapless Oscar de la Renta gown. Jenner, Kardashian and Kim Kardashian agreed that was the one.
“I’ve never been in such a beautiful dress. I mean, this is just stunning,” Zettel said of the gown.
“It looks like it was made just for you,” Khloé Kardashian said.
Scroll below to learn all about the Kardashians’ cousin Natalie Zettel.
Natalie Zettel is a model
According to her Instagram bio, Zettel is a “fashion model.”
She is also affiliated with the company Styles by Nat, which is an “unlimited rental subscription service that makes it easy to wear new looks all month long without any commitment,” per its website.
She's 26 years old
According to public records, Zettel was born in January of 1998, making her 26 years old. Her cousin, Kylie Jenner, is her cousin closest in age, and was born in August 1997.
Natalie Zettel’s mother was her ‘best friend’
Zettel’s mother, Karen Houghton, died of a heart attack in March 2024. Kris Jenner confirmed the cause of death on "The Kardashians."
In her tribute on Instagram, Zettel said she was always really close with her mother.

“You were my best friend, my everything. The best mother a daughter could ever ask for and I’m so grateful to have had a mother like you,” she said at the time. “You were the most kind, sweet, loving, giving, and caring soul. You had the biggest heart. And I don’t know how to go on without you. It all happened so quick & I wasn’t ready for you to go. An angel was sent to heaven on March 18th, 2024. I love you mommy and you will forever be missed.”
Kris Jenner attended Natalie Zettel's wedding
Zettel and her boyfriend, Noah Warren, had a beachfront wedding on March 2, 2025. For the event, she wore the same Oscar de la Renta gown that Kris Jenner bought for her on "The Kardashians."
On Instagram, Jenner revealed that she attended her niece's wedding when she shared a few happy photos of the celebration online.

She penned the caption, "Last weekend was a dream in La Jolla, California, celebrating my beautiful niece Natalie’s wedding! Such a magical day filled with love, laughter, and unforgettable moments. Congratulations, Natalie and Noah! Wishing you both a lifetime of happiness! ❤️✨👰🏻🤵🏻 @nataliezettel @noah_warren721 Thank you @oscardelarenta for the absolutely GORGEOUS gown!!!!"
Natalie Zettel's husband is a fishing captain
Zettle's husband, Noah Warren, is the captain of Blue Ocean Sportfishing, which is a company that takes people on fishing trips and sunset cruises.
According to the company's website, Warren got into fishing from "his early days as a pinhead on local cattle boats."
"Now, with 14 years of experience under his belt, Noah runs his own operation and is eager to share his passion for the sea with you," the site states.

title: Reba McEntire pays tribute to country queens Patsy Cline, Loretta Lynn with ‘Opry 100’ performance
summary: Reba McEntire opened the “Opry 100: A Live Celebration” by honoring her two country heroes; Patsy Cline and Loretta Lynn.
story: Reba McEntire opened the “Opry 100: A Live Celebration” by honoring her two country heroes; Patsy Cline and Loretta Lynn.
The country star kicked off the March 19 show with an a cappella version of Cline’s “Sweet Dreams (Of You).”

“It’s an honor to be here celebrating 100 years of the Grand Ole Opry,” she said. “So many trailblazers paved the way for me to have the privilege of standing on this stage tonight, like two of my heroes, the great Patsy Cline and Loretta Lynn.”
McEntire continued by performing a rendition of “You Ain’t Woman Enough” by Lynn.
She was then joined by Trisha Yearwood and the two country stars sang “The Night the Lights Went Out in Georgia.” The song is by Vicki Lawrence, but was covered by McEntire in 1991.
NBC's “Opry 100: A Live Celebration” is a three-hour live concert held at the Nashville concert hall to celebrate its 100th birthday.
Hosted by Blake Shelton, a slew of stars took the stage like Carrie Underwood, Post Malone, Garth Brooks, Alan Jackson, Kelsea Ballerini and many more.

title: Ellen Pompeo on 'Grey's Anatomy' salary fight: ‘It’s my face, it's my voice'
summary: Ellen Pompeo spoke about her experience navigating a pay gap between her and her "Grey's Anatomy" co-star Patrick Dempsey.
story: Ellen Pompeo has candid thoughts about her experience of "Grey's Anatomy," specifically regarding negotiating her salary.

In the latest episode of "Call Her Daddy," Pompeo didn't hold back on the pay gap between her and her former "Grey's Anatomy" co-star Patrick Dempsey. Recognizing his status as the bigger name at the start of the series, she said he had more experience filming TV pilots than her, meaning his quote was higher.
“To be completely fair, the television game was so different then. And he had done, like, 13 pilots before me. That was my first pilot I had ever done,” Pompeo recalled.
“So if you’ve done 13 TV pilots — nothing personal to him, but just in general — only a man can fail, can have 13 failed TV pilots, and their quote still keeps going up, right?” she added.

While acknowledging that Dempsey had built a reputation in the industry before the hit ABC series began, Pompeo described feeling frustration at the disparity, as she was playing the show's titular character.
“I wasn’t salty about him getting what he got. I was salty that they didn’t value me as much as they valued him," she explained.
After gaining experience and seeing how the show was performing, Pompeo said she leveraged that knowledge to negotiate her salary.

“I see exactly how much 'Grey’s Anatomy' makes for ABC, Disney. I get to see the number," she said. "And then, you know, it’s my face, it’s my voice. I’ve done so much work promoting the show all over the world for the past 20 years.”
Now, the actor said she's committed to helping women who don't have the same insider knowledge.

“You really do have a responsibility to look and see what everybody else is making and use your power to say, ‘Listen, I appreciate what I got. This is amazing, but I happen to notice this, and I really think that all the women deserve a bump,’” she said.

title: Jonathan Majors confirms marriage to Meagan Good
summary: Jonathan Majors revealed in a new interview that he and Meagan Good got married March 18, sharing details of the intimate wedding ceremony on "Sherri."
story: Jonathan Majors and Meagan Good have tied the knot.
Majors confirmed on “Sherri” that he and the actor got married Tuesday, March 18, calling it one of the happiest days of his life.
“I said to Meagan yesterday, I said, ‘Today might be the happiest day of my life,’” Majors, 35, said during his March 19 appearance on the show. “I love that woman so much."
The “Magazine Dreams” star continued to share more about their wedding while wiping away happy tears.
“I asked her father first in Paris if that was alright, and he said, ‘That’s cool,’” he said. “It was a longer conversation ... So it was always the plan.”
The actor shared that his mother is a pastor and came from Dallas to a Los Angeles screening of his latest movie.
“My mother had never been to one of my screenings. And we had told her that, ‘Hey we’re gonna do this thing.’ And we did,” he continued. “My mother married us yesterday. Her mother was there.”
“We had these rings and we got them engraved in Hawaii after I spoke with her father again,” he added. “We finally got to do it, but it was always the plan.”

The actors first confirmed their engagement on Nov. 17, 2024, when they attended the Ebony Power 100 Gala. Good, at the time, showed off her engagement ring while telling "E! News" they had “two proposals.”

“We did two proposals,” she revealed, before noting they were going to keep details of the moment private. “We’re going to keep it to ourselves, but it was very — I was very shocked, and it was wonderful. And I was like, ‘Wait, are you serious, babe?’”
The “Divorce in the Black” star later added that they had a second proposal “some months later.”
At the time, they shared that they had met at the same event “two years ago.”
“Ebony Power 100 is the event that we met at, in the bathroom, in the unisex bathroom,” Good said.
The pair first sparked romance rumors in May 2023, months after Majors was arrested on domestic violence allegations after his ex-girlfriend Grace Jabbari alleged she was assaulted.
A spokesperson for the actor denied the allegations in a statement to TODAY.com at the time, stating, “He has done nothing wrong. We look forward to clearing his name and clearing this up.”

Good stood by Majors’ side during the trial, even after he was found guilty of misdemeanor assault and harassment on Dec. 18, 2023. In April of the following year, the “Creed III” actor was sentenced to one year of counseling, probation and a $250 fine, according to NBC News.
Following the sentencing, Good spoke about her relationship with Majors.

“I take everyone’s opinion and advice into account, for sure, but at the end of the day, I’m the one who has to live my life. I’m the one who has to get to heaven one day, prayerfully, and give God an account of what I did,” she said during a July 2024 appearance on TODAY with Hoda & Jenna. “So, I want to be responsible for the choices that I make. I also want to live the life that I want to live.”

title: 'Good American Family': Where are Michael and Kristine Barnett now?
summary: Where are Michael and Kristine Barnett, the former adoptive parents of Natalia Grace, now?
story: Natalia Grace and one set of her former adoptive parents, Michael and Kristine Barnett, are the subject of a new series, “Good American Family.”
Their story played out in the media and has been the focus of two film projects: a documentary series, “The Curious Case of Natalia Grace,” and now the Hulu drama.

The couple is played by Ellen Pompeo and Mark Duplass in the series. In an interview with TODAY.com, Duplass said the role of Michael Barnett was a “joy,” because it allowed him to have “latitude” as an actor.

“This is a story about perspective, right? And because we see this story from so many different perspectives, that means the character of Michael Barnett is so many different things at any given time. And sometimes he seems sweet and intensely paternal and morally centered, and sometimes he feels a little bit manipulative, but sometimes he feels desperate,” he said — adding that the role is also “deeply unsettling.”
Showrunner Katie Robbins said the show was created without being in touch with the real people.

“We weren’t in touch with anybody, which made having the copious amounts of research that we have that much more essential,’ she said. TODAY.com has reached out to Michael and Kristine Barnett for comment and has not heard back by the time of publication.
Where are the real Michael and Kristine Barnett now? Here’s what to know.
Who are Michael and Kristine Barnett?

Michael and Kristine Barnett are a formerly married couple who adopted Natalia Grace, an orphan from Ukraine, in 2010, according to a 2021 document from the Court of Appeals in Indiana reviewing two aspects from the Barnetts’ 2021 trials obtained by TODAY.com.

They already had three biological sons, Jacob, Ethan and Wesley. In the book “The Spark: A Mother’s Story of Nurturing Genius,” Kristine Barnett wrote about raising her eldest son, who she says in the book as diagnosed with autism at 2 and also is a math and science prodigy. The Washington Post called the memoir “amazing” and “compulsive reading.”

The Barnetts previously ran a charity called Jacob’s Place, which had the purpose of raising awareness about autism and funded “programs that bring joy to children on the spectrum,” according to an archived version of the charity’s website.
What happened between the Barnetts and Natalia Grace?

Michael and Kristine Barnett said they began to suspect that Grace, who has a rare form of dwarfism, was a grown woman masquerading as a little girl, per the court document from the Court of Appeals in Indiana obtained by TODAY.com.
They also accused Grace of threatening their family with violence, per the Court of Appeals document, which Grace has long denied.
Grace was psychologically and medically evaluated between 2010 and 2012, per the document from the Court of Appeals in Indiana.

In 2012, the Barnetts filed a successful petition to change Grace’s legal birth year from 2003 to 1989 to reflect an older age. The following year, they moved to Canada with their biological children and left Grace alone in a rented apartment to transition to “life as an adult,” according the court document from the Court of Appeals in Indiana.

Medical records, however, said Grace was not an adult. According to a 2019 affidavit of probable cause, Grace was examined by a doctor at Peyton Manning Children’s Hospital that determined she was 8 years old in 2010. A 2012 skeletal survey at the same hospital determined she was 11. Per the affidavit, Michael Barnett admitted he and Kristine were aware of these examinations and test results when they left her alone in an apartment in 2013.

Cynthia and Antwan Mans, a Tippecanoe County couple, filed for legal guardianship of Grace in 2016. Michael Barnett filed an objection, “asserting that Natalia was an adult,” per the document from the Indiana Court of Appeals. This sparked years of legal back-and-forth.

In 2019, the Barnetts were each charged with six counts of neglect of a dependent and two counts of conspiracy to commit neglect of a dependent. After a protracted legal process, Michael Barnett was acquitted of his charges after a jury trial in 2022 and the charges against his wife were dismissed.
Michael Barnett filed for divorce from Kristine Barnett in 2014, and their divorce was finalized in 2018, according to Indiana court records seen by TODAY.com.
What have they said about their time with Natalia Grace?
Kristine Barnett has denied accusations that Grace was abused while living with her and her ex-husband.

“Natalia was a very much loved and cared for member of my family. She was not abused by anyone in my family. Let’s get straight to these allegations. Nobody ever took a belt to Natalia and the allegations that she was ‘beaten’ are just plain false,” she wrote in part of a since-deleted Facebook post from January 2024.
She added that “any discipline of Natalia was very minimal” and “not out of the bounds of normal parenting.”
Kristine Barnett has since removed all posts about Natalia Grace from her Facebook page.
She did not participate in the Investigation Discovery documentary about Grace’s case, but Michael Barnett was interviewed for the docuseries.
In one dramatic scene, he and Grace discuss their past relationship. He accuses his ex-wife of emotional abuse and argues that he and Grace were both victims in their home.

“I had the same monster you did. I was exceptionally controlled and put down and threatened, was minimalized,” he told Grace. “Who I was was ripped from me, and I was guided and instructed to be exactly what she wanted me to be.”
In her deleted Facebook post, Kristine Barnett appeared to address her ex-husband’s allegations.
“Michael Barnett and Natalia Barnett may have the same monster but that monster is not me,” she wrote.
Grace no longer lives with either of the Barnetts. As of early 2025, she was living with another family, the DePauls, and working on becoming more independent, she told People in January.
Where are Michael and Kristine Barnett now?

As of 2023, Barnett appeared to still be living in Indianapolis, Indiana. A 2023 court document related to a speeding violation lists the same Indianapolis address for Barnett as was listed in the 2019 case involving the multiple charges of neglect against him and his ex-wife.
Barnett appears to have remarried and divorced following his split with Kristine Barnett.

According to Indiana court records, a petitioner listed as Michael Barnett with the same Indianapolis address as above filed for divorce against a respondent named Jennifer Barnett. Their divorce was finalized in 2022.
In a 2018 court document confirming her divorce from Michael Barnett, Kristine Barnett was listed as residing in New Hamburg, Ontario.
By 2019, she appears to have moved back to the United States. A court document listed her address as located in Indiana.

title: All the artists performing at the Opry's 100th anniversary special, from Blake Shelton to Reba McEntire
